MemberSignature.Value: public static Windows.Foundation.TimeSpan GetDwellDuration (Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype Windows.Foundation.TimeSpan GetDwellDuration([in]class Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element) runtime managed
Public Shared Function GetDwellDuration (element As UIElement) As TimeSpan

public static TimeSpan GetDwellDuration (Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.TimeSpan GetDwellDuration(class Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element) cil managed
static member GetDwellDuration : Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement -> TimeSpan

Docs.summary: Gets the duration for the control to transition from the Fixation state to the Dwell state. At this point, a StateChanged event is fired with PointerState set to Dwell. The Enter and Fixation states are typically achieved too rapidly for the user to have much control over. In contrast Dwell is conscious event. This is the point at which the control is invoked, e.g. a button click. The application can modify this property to control when a gaze enabled UI element gets invoked after a user starts looking at it.
Docs.returns: The duration for the control to transition from the Fixation state to the Dwell state.

public static TimeSpan GetDwellRepeatDuration (Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.TimeSpan GetDwellRepeatDuration(class Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element) cil managed
static member GetDwellRepeatDuration : Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement -> TimeSpan

Docs.summary: Gets the duration of repeated dwell invocations, should the user continue to dwell on the control. The first repeat will occur after an additional delay specified by RepeatDelayDuration. Subsequent repeats happen after every period of DwellRepeatDuration. A control is invoked repeatedly only if MaxDwellRepeatCount is set to greater than zero.
Docs.returns: The duration of repeated dwell invocations.

MemberSignature.Value: public static Windows.Foundation.TimeSpan GetFixationDuration (Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element);

static member GetFixationDuration : Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement -> TimeSpan

Docs.summary: Gets the duration for the control to transition from the Enter state to the Fixation state. At this point, a StateChanged event is fired with PointerState set to Fixation. This event should be used to control the earliest visual feedback the application needs to provide to the user about the gaze location. The default is 350ms.
Docs.returns: Duration for the control to transition from the Enter state to the Fixation state.

.method public static hidebysig int32 GetMaxDwellRepeatCount(class Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element) cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets the maximum times the control will invoked repeatedly without the user's gaze having to leave and re-enter the control. The default value is zero which disables repeated invocation of a control. Developers can set a higher value to enable repeated invocation.
Docs.returns: The maximum times the control will invoked repeatedly without the user's gaze having to leave and re-enter the control.

MemberSignature.Value: public static Windows.Foundation.TimeSpan GetThresholdDuration (Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element);

.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.TimeSpan GetThresholdDuration(class Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement element) cil managed
static member GetThresholdDuration : Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement -> TimeSpan

Docs.summary: Gets the duration that controls when the PointerState moves to either the Enter state or the Exit state. When this duration has elapsed after the user's gaze first enters a control, the PointerState is set to Enter. And when this duration has elapsed after the user's gaze has left the control, the PointerState is set to Exit. In both cases, a StateChanged event is fired. The default is 50ms.
Docs.returns: The duration that controls when the PointerState moves to either the Enter state or the Exit state.

static member SetThresholdDuration : Windows.UI.Xaml.UIElement * TimeSpan -> unit

Docs.summary: Sets the duration that controls when the PointerState moves to either the Enter state or the Exit state. When this duration has elapsed after the user's gaze first enters a control, the PointerState is set to Enter. And when this duration has elapsed after the user's gaze has left the control, the PointerState is set to Exit. In both cases, a StateChanged event is fired. The default is 50ms.
